Introduction

According to Dickinson (1938), Fermat stated the following in 1637:

It is impossible to separate a cube into two cubes, or a biquadrate into two biquadrates, or in general any power higher than the second into the power of like degree; I have discovered a truly remarkable proof which this margin is too small to contain.”

This theorem is now known as Fermat’s Last Theorem, and it can be stated as follows.

Conclusion

In this post we saw how the Chebotarev density theorem can be used as a very efficient “machine” to produce arithmetic information.

Starting from the simple observation that Frobenius elements encode splitting behaviour, we deduced that totally split primes always exist in abundance (in fact with positive density), and we used this to prove a rigidity statement: in the Galois case, knowing which primes split completely already determines the extension.

We also proved Dirichlet’s theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions by applying Chebotarev to cyclotomic fields, and we saw a typical application to polynomials: if an irreducible polynomial has a root modulo almost every prime, then it must be linear.

All these results share the same pattern: translate a question into a condition on Frobenius conjugacy classes, then use Chebotarev to conclude that the relevant primes not only exist, but are infinitely many.

Introduction

In the previous post we asked some questions about prime numbers such as:

  • Which numbers could be written as the product of primes?
  • How many primes are there?

The goal of this post is to give a precise answer to these two questions.

The first person to rigorously answer these questions was the Greek mathematician Euclid, and we will roughly follow his reasoning.

What a prime is?

Let’s start with a short recap. In school we learned that a positive integer is prime if its only divisors are and itself ( is not considered prime). So we have that are the first few primes.

Consider the prime . Note that every time divides a product of two integers , it divides one of the two factors (i.e. either divides or divides ). Try a few examples to convince yourself. For instance, divides the product and indeed divides . You can try any product and the property will hold. There is nothing special about ; indeed, every prime number satisfies this (i.e. if a prime number divides a product then either divides or divides ). Note that this property characterises primes. For example, observe that (which isn’t prime) divides the product , but divides neither nor .

Since this property is important, we define prime numbers as follows:

Definition: An integer is prime if whenever divides a product , then divides or divides .

We will instead use the term irreducible for the other definition we know:

Definition: An integer is irreducible if its only divisors are itself,, and .

We include because we allow negative integers; for instance is irreducible since its only divisors are , , and .

For integers, a number is irreducible if and only if it is prime, so the two definitions agree. This is why we often use the irreducible definition for primes.

Back to school: the Euclidean division

We know how division of integers works. For example, to divide by we count how many times can be added without exceeding . We see that , so the quotient is and the remainder is . We write in symbols

Another example: dividing by yields quotient and remainder , i.e.

As a final example, suppose we want to divide by . Since is too big, the quotient is and the remainder is , i.e.

We learned that we can always perform division with remainder: for positive integers we can write

where is the quotient and is the remainder. We are ready to state this as a theorem:

Theorem 1 (Euclidean division.) For every two integers and (we cannot divide by ), there exist integers such that

where . Moreover and are uniquely determined.

Okay, pause for a moment: this theorem seems more complicated than it should be. First, it should be clear that we can write our as

for some and . Why must be strictly less than ? Because if it were not, we could divide further. For example suppose we write

This is not admissible, since ; we can still divide by to get

Now, since is smaller than , we cannot divide it again, so we are done and what we get is the division.

The other question is: what does it mean that and are uniquely determined? It means there is only one way to write as , with . Take a pen and paper and try to convince yourself that this writing is unique by doing some example.

The fundamental theorem of arithmetic

Now we want to answer the question of which numbers could be written as a product of primes. The following theorem gives us the answer.

Theorem 2 (Fundamental theorem of arithmetic.) Every integer strictly bigger than one (i.e. ) can be written uniquely as the product of prime numbers.

This helps us understand why primes are so important. In this sense they are the basic building blocks of the integers. We can always decompose an integer as the product of primes and this is done uniquely.

Let’s give some examples to clarify the theorem. Consider . Its prime divisors are and so . Another example could be ; it is divided only by , so .

How do we factor a number in practice? Pick an integer, for example . We look at the first few primes

and test the divisibility by successive primes:

  • Is divisible by ? Yes: .
  • Is divisible by ? Yes: .
  • Is divisible by ? No: we move on to the next prime.
  • Is divisible by ? Yes: .

So we get

By this process we can factor any positive integer. For negative integers, include a leading minus sign; e.g. .

Now consider . Since it is prime, it can’t be factorized further. Therefore, we will say that its factorization is just itself, i.e. given by

where on the right hand side we are writing the factors (just ) of the factorization.

We want to convince ourselves that a factorization always exists, so we dive into its proof.

Proof (Existence of the prime factorization). Suppose some positive integers could not be factorized. Take the smallest such integer and call it . The integer cannot be a prime number, since if it were its factorization would be (as we did in the case of ). Since is not prime, there must be some number other than and which divides it. We can therefore write for some other integer . But now observe that and are both smaller than . Since was the smallest such number that could not be factorized, both and can be factorized into prime factors. In particular we get that

This yields a factorization of . For example, ; factoring gives and , hence

Therefore, we proved that the smallest number which couldn’t be factorized can actually be factorized. Hence, we get the claim.

Moreover, the theorem tells us that the factorization is unique: you can’t write an integer () as a product of primes in two different ways. Try some examples to convince yourself.

How many primes are there?

Finally, we are ready to answer this question. You may have guessed the answer, but I really want to give a neat argument that will convince you it is true.

Theorem 3 There exist infinitely many prime numbers.

Proof (Euclid’s proof). Suppose there were only finitely many prime numbers, call them . Define as the product of all these primes plus , i.e.

Observe that is not divisible by any of the primes . To convince ourselves, take and write

Define . We are saying

Thus, has remainder when divided by , so does not divide (if it did the remainder would be ). Nothing is special about : we can repeat the same argument for all the other primes .

So we are convinced that no prime in the list divides .

But we said (Theorem 2) that any integer number can be written as the product of primes. However, since is not divisible by any prime in the list , it means that the list does not contain all of the primes.

Hence, whenever we suppose a finite list contains all primes, we can construct a prime not in the list; thus any finite list is incomplete.

We conclude that there must be infinitely many primes.

Conclusion

To prove there are infinitely many primes we used a common strategy. We understood that proving the statement as it appears is very difficult. How can you prove there are infinitely many primes? The natural idea is: suppose there were only finitely many, and derive a contradiction. This is what we call a proof by contradiction (you prove your claim by proving that its negation is false).

There is another cool idea we used today. When we proved Theorem 2 we had the idea of supposing that there were some numbers not satisfying our statement. Then we took the minimum among these numbers and proved that the minimum actually satisfied our claim. This kind of argument is often called proof by minimal counterexample (a form of induction), and it is also common.

Think about these two kinds of proofs and how we used them in the arguments. If you’d like to practice, try proving uniqueness of prime factorization (proceed by contradiction and use the two definitions of prime introduced above).

In any case, see you next week!

item.title: Introduction to Fermat’s Christmas Theorem
item.description:
ENG ITA

Some history

On Christmas day (25 December 1640), Pierre de Fermat wrote a letter to Marin Mersenne where he stated that every prime number of the form could be written as the sum of two squares. He claimed to have an irrefutable proof of the statement.

The result was already conjectured by Albert Girard, but the first complete proof was given by Leonhard Euler, who announced it in a letter sent to Christian Goldbach.

Today the theorem is known as “Fermat’s theorem on sums of two squares” or “Fermat’s Christmas Theorem”, because of the date in which Fermat claimed to have the proof.

Detailed historical information can be found in the relevant chapter of Dickinson (1938).

Random thoughts sometimes are nice

We’re bored, so we start writing some useless calculations in our notebook. We really like prime numbers (we’ll explain why later in the posts), so we start by writing a few of them:

Since we have nothing better to do, we start asking some questions about them, like:

  • how many prime numbers are there?
  • which numbers could be expressed as the product of prime numbers?

We like these questions (and will answer them in the next few posts), but in the process we ask a more subtle one:

Question: When can we write a prime number as the sum of two squares? In other words, when can we write with and are integers?

We try to approach the problem by trial and error to understand it better.

  • Consider the prime number . Can we write it as the sum of two squares? Well, there aren’t many ways to write as a sum of two integers: But since we have therefore we can indeed write as the sum of two squares.

  • Let’s try with : the only possible ways of writing as a sum of two numbers are and However and are not squares, so does not have the property.

  • We move on to the number : we can write it as , but since and are not squares, we have to search for another writing, that we find in , since and .

  • What about ? Well, we can write as:

    • , but is not a square;
    • , but is not a square;
    • , but neither nor are squares;
    • , but is not a square. therefore cannot be written as the sum of two squares.

Continuing this process, we find that among the primes in the list above, those that satisfy the property are:

We want to investigate further the properties of these primes. First, observe that we are only interested in odd primes (i.e., all primes other than ), since we already know that can be written as the sum of two squares. Therefore, we start to look at them carefully and conjecture the following fact:

All odd primes that can be written as the sum of two squares have remainder when divided by .

However, this only tells us that if an odd prime is a sum of two squares, then it leaves remainder when divided by . But in general it’s not easy to check whether a prime is the sum of two squares, since we’d have to try many possibilities (look at and imagine larger primes). If we just want to know whether a prime has remainder when divided by , we can compute that quickly and save time.

But maybe we didn’t waste our time thinking about this problem. Since we can easily check what is the remainder of a prime when divided by , what if we can write an odd prime as the sum of two squares each time it has remainder in such a division? That would be great: we could avoid long case checks and simply compute the remainder, like we learned in elementary school. Luckily, the theorem we want to focus on gives us the answer:

Theorem 1 (Fermat’s Christmas Theorem) An odd prime number can be written as the sum of two squares if and only if it has remainder when divided by .

Now we see why the theorem is nice: it simplifies a difficult problem (determining whether an odd prime is the sum of two squares) to a simple one (checking whether its remainder is when divided by ).

In the next posts we will develop the necessary tools step by step, until we can give a complete proof of Fermat’s Christmas Theorem.

Some plan for the future

I chose to talk about this theorem because, to me, the most interesting part is its proof. As a math student I spend most of my time trying to understand proofs (for me, mathematics is mostly about them).

Maybe some of you are asking yourselves:

What is a mathematical proof?

This isn’t an easy question (it’s rather philosophical). Anyway, we can think of a proof as an argument convincing us about the truth of some proposition. Probably not all the arguments I share will be full formal proofs, since I won’t always be very formal. My goal is to convey the general ideas rather than the technical details. I hope the careful reader will forgive me if I sometimes prefer simplicity to rigor.

The aim is to help interested readers convince themselves of Fermat’s Christmas Theorem and to explain some basic mathematical ideas along the way.

A rough plan for the proof will involve:

  • talking about general properties of integers
  • talking about modular arithmetic
  • talking about Gaussian integers
  • putting everything together

I hope you enjoy the process as much as I did the first time I learned these beautiful ideas.

See you soon!
